awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Unmanned Aerial Vehicles for Emissions and Chemistry of Volatile Organic Compounds over the Amazon Tropical Forest
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will improve the understanding of atmospheric chemistry processes over tropical forest ecosystems.  A mobile profiling system will be used to characterize emissions and deposition of volatile organic compounds (VOC) over horizontal and vertical scales across different forest sub-types.  The data will be collected during a series of drone-enabled experiments conducted in both wet and dry seasons in the Adolfo Ducke Forest Reserve, located on the northern outskirts of Manaus Brazil in central Amazonia.  The results will be used to improve atmospheric chemistry modeling and databases that characterize the emissions of biogenic compounds from vegetation.

The scientific questions that will be addressed during this project include the following: (1) What is the horizontal heterogeneity in the magnitude and types of VOC emission and deposition for forest landscapes that vary on intermediate scales of 100's m?  (2) What is the vertical heterogeneity and diel cycle of reactive VOCs in a turbulent planetary boundary layer? and (3) What is the vertical heterogeneity in the speciation and concentration of semivolatile organic compounds (SVOC) produced as photochemical reaction products of VOC oxidation?

The horizontal protocol will characterize the spatial variability of the sampled VOCs at intermediate scale and be used to constrain and improve MEGAN (Model of Emissions of Gases and Aerosols from Nature), a framework used for modeling biogenic emissions.  The data obtained by the vertical protocol will be used with the mixed-layer inverse-model technique to estimate VOC fluxes. The data and insights gained from this effort will be used to constrain and improve current chemical transport models of atmospheric oxidation and to provide a better understanding of regional and global chemical transport in Amazonia, especially as related to mechanisms of  SVOCs and particulate matter production and susceptibility to future Earth-system changes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) play critical roles in biological signaling and functioning and in atmospheric chemistry over forest ecosystems where they are widely recognized as important for regional air quality and global climate due to their impacts on atmospheric ozone, hydroxyl radicals, and secondary organic aerosol (SOA). The magnitude and diversity of VOC emissions and concentrations are not well known especially over regions of high diversity such as the tropical forests of Amazonia. The limited understanding of these emissions is at least partly due to a lack of suitable observational tools. The unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) sampling platform and the low cost/power eddy flux systems developed for this project have improved observational capabilities leading to advances in understanding the processes controlling biogenic VOC emissions and chemistry.

The UAV sampling platform enables investigations of moderate scale (tens of meters) variations in reactive compounds that was previously unavailable. It was used in this project to investigate near-canopy horizontal concentration heterogeneity of semivolatile oxygenated organic compounds (SV-OVOCs). The results revealed that some, but not all, SV-OVOCs are dominated by primary emissions. This includes 2-methyltetrols which models previously assumed were entirely secondary production. This is an important distinction because 2-methyltetrols formed from secondary processes have a much lower impact on SOA production while primary emissions can have a significant impact. The finding of substantial primary emissions of 2-methyltetrols has enabled regional models to reconcile aircraft observations of SOA that were underestimated by models, especially at higher altitudes. This demonstrates that in-plant biochemistry plays a central role in SOA formation and biosphere-atmosphere interactions in Amazonia. The UAV sampling also enabled the identification and quantitative characterization of the river breeze occurrence and the effect on pollutant recirculation in Amazonia which has implications for the health of millions of inhabitants in this region. The results showed that the river breeze circulation occurred in about 80% of cases and that the impacts of this local circulation can be considerable.

The UAV sampling platform and eddy flux measurement systems have been described in detail and these tools are being adopted by other investigators. The BVOC observations from this project have been integrated into the emission factor database of the widely used BVOC emission model, MEGANv3.2, and made available to the scientific and air quality regulatory community for regional to global emission modeling. Training provided to US and Brazilian undergraduate and graduate students has improved their expertise for specific technical skills and broadened their understanding of Earth System science.
